content.raw: It should be noted that this pull request addresses Issue #38

content.raw: I can't seem to find a difference. I was thinking that it might matter for numbers that round to floats like `9007199254740993.0` which aren't actually representable in IEEE 754. But it doesn't seem to.
content.html: I can't seem to find a difference. I was thinking that it might matter for numbers that round to floats like 9007199254740993.0 which aren't actually representable in IEEE 754. But it doesn't seem to.

content.raw: You could add an assertion instead.

update.description: fix cast float to int numpy arrays described in the Issue #38
update.title: Default

content.raw: Specifically I believe he means he is going to fix the description. The dtype argument is only for the issue of `round`ing / casting to int array.
content.html: Specifically I believe he means he is going to fix the description. The dtype argument is only for the issue of rounding / casting to int array.

content.raw: Should it be removed (along with the comments)? I don't know if tests cover this case.
content.html: Should it be removed (along with the comments)? I don't know if tests cover this case.

content.raw:
Could you point out what the difference might be? An example?
Do you mean that the original code was probably flooring the result?
content.html: Could you point out what the difference might be? An example? Do you mean that the original code was probably flooring the result?

content.raw: True, that was overwritten by my last commit... I'll fix that
content.html: True, that was overwritten by my last commit... I'll fix that

content.raw: yes
content.html: yes

content.raw: Does `linspace(start, end, 0)` always return `array([])` as before?
content.html: Does linspace(start, end, 0) always return array([]) as before?

content.raw: This creates intermediate `float` array and then converts to `int`, which may not be the same as `round`ing straight into an `int` array.
content.html: This creates intermediate float array and then converts to int, which may not be the same as rounding straight into an int array.

content.raw: This does not use the `dtype` argument as described in the description.
content.html: This does not use the dtype argument as described in the description.

content.raw: This code shouldn't be needed. The number of bins should never be less than 0. I assume the way it was before was a hyper-correctness thing.
content.html: This code shouldn't be needed. The number of bins should never be less than 0. I assume the way it was before was a hyper-correctness thing.

content.raw: @hoffman ready for your review
content.html: @hoffman ready for your review

content.raw: This seems like a valid comment to leave in but I'm not certain.
content.html: This seems like a valid comment to leave in but I'm not certain.

content.raw: No it was not so I fixed it. As far as I understand it won't cause a bug if it's not rounded but it's more accurate.
content.html: No it was not so I fixed it. As far as I understand it won't cause a bug if it's not rounded but it's more accurate.

update.description:
* fix casting error in aggregation.py Issue #38 .

* use new built-in linspace dtype argument to return an array of int instead of casting manually.
update.title: Default

content.raw: Is the `round` operation accounted for that was used previously in `calc_bin_starts` ? Admittedly I'm not sure why it would be needed in the first place?
content.html: Is the round operation accounted for that was used previously in calc_bin_starts ? Admittedly I'm not sure why it would be needed in the first place?
